text.p: These are the leading stories in Pakistani newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
THE NEWS

- Water and Power Minister Chaudhry Nisar Ali Khan told reportes in Islamabad on Wednesday that subsidy on electricity available to Federal Administered Tribal Areas and most areas of Azad Kashmir and Baluchistan would be withdrawn to cut deficit being faced by the Water and Power Development Authority.

- The ruling Pakistan Muslim League party on Wednesday voted out in the National Assembly a private bill sponsored by the Pakistan People's Party which sought a constitutional amendment to resotre special women's seats in parliament.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has expressed his dissatisfaction with law and order situation in Punjab.
- The government is seriously considering to start a Karachi-like clean-up operation in Punjab province to uproot elements involved in sectarian violence and terrorism.
The Punjab provincial government has decided to establish Suppression of Terrorist Activities courts for the trial of sectarian and terrorism cases.
DAWN
- Pakistan has received a very positive response from abroad for introducing a capital market development package on Tuesday, says Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz.

- Pakistani banks and development financial institutions recovered 2.6 billion rupees from loan defaulters of 1.0 million rupees and above during September-December 1996, bringing down the stuck-up loans from 123 billion rupees to 121 billion.

- The government will have to pay penalties of $20,000 per megawatt per month from November this year to foreign power companies, besides suffering incalculable revenue losses as it has failed to construct 500 kv transmission line to connect the national grid system to the new private power units.
- The visiting officials of the World Bank who met top bankers on Wednesday were of the view that in addition to the United Bank Ltd and Habib Bank Ltd, the National Bank should also be privatised.
THE MUSLIM

- The Pakistan People's Party, after a meeting of its central executive committee in Islamabad, said on Wednesday that the Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's government had failed on all fronts and feared that the deteriorating law and order situation in the country would further aggravate the crisis.
THE NATION

- Parliamentarians of the ruling Pakistan Muslim League in the National Assembly on Wednesday demanded fixation of a mark-up rate of six percent for agricultural loans while coming hard upon the industrialist class of the country.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- The government will be inclined to immediately cancel the agreements for independent power projects if any violation of the agreed terms is found.
- The business leaders praising the attitude of top bosses of the Central Board of Revenue have announced to launch a campaign for doubling the total of tax revenues.

- Pakistan, once reputed as the granary of the sub-continent and boasting agricultural economy, was forced to import 12.18 million tonnes of wheat worth $2.261 billion from the United States, Australia, Canada, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Europe from 1989/90 to 1996/97, Food Minister Abida Hussain told the National Assembly (lower house) on Wednesday.
FINANCIAL POST
- Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz has said that basic reforms in financial management of the government will be introduced besides strengthening institutions such as audit department.
